Name: Is there a distinct category of dual for verbal agreement with a dual subject?
Is non-agreement in number between the nominal subject and verbal predicate possible?
Comment: The finite verbs agree with the nominal subject. Non-agreement is possible only between plural and dual in certain sentence types, like habitual and existential.

Name: Can finite verbs agree in number with the nominal object?
Can an adnominal property word agree with the noun in case?
Comment: Adjectives in Inari Saami don't usually agree with the nouns, instead an attributive form is used with adjectives, e.g. puáris tááluin (old.ATTR house.PL.LOC) 'in old houses'. Pronouns and numerals agree in some cases fully and in some cases partially, e.g. tain tááluin (this.PL.LOC house.PL.LOC) 'in these houses', taan táálust (this.SG.GEN house.SG.LOC) 'in this house'. Finally, there are some adjectives that either are considered to follow the same rule as the pronouns and numerals, or as a variation have the attributive form.

Name: Are there cases that do not show agreement in terms of case?
Comment: The partial agreement cases in singular are the locative, illative, and abessive, in plural there is no agreement in comitative and abessive. With these cases the adnominal property word is in the genitive form (in SG or PL).

Name: Can adpositions be used to mark core verbal arguments?
Can adpositions be used to mark non-core/oblique verbal arguments?
Can non-finite clauses entail a special way for a core argument (S/A) marking?
Can non-finite clauses entail a special way for a core argument (P) marking?
Do characteristics of object referent (topicality, animacy, definiteness) influence object marking?
Does object marking correlate with aspectuality?
Does the marking of the object depend on the verb conjugation form?
Is there differential subject marking?
Can S and A be conflated morphologically across clause boundaries, i.e. act as syntactic pivot?
Can S and P be conflated morphologically across clause boundaries, i.e. act as syntactic pivot?
Is there a grammatical device for habituality?
Is there a grammatical device for frequentative?
Comment: It is possible to derive frequentative verbs from other verbs with various derivative markers.

Name: Is there a grammatical device for progressivity?
Is it common to use a verb in the present tense for future time reference?
Comment: There is no future tense in Inari Saami. The present tense can be used to mean something that will happen in the future.

Name: Is there a grammatical device for immediate future?
Comment: Depending on the verb aspect, the structure 'is happening' can mean immediate future.

Name: Is there a grammatical device for pluperfect?
Can aspect be expressed overtly on the negative marker?
Can tense be expressed overtly on the negative marker?
Is there grammatical marking of mirativity?
Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of desire or wish?
Is there morphological marking for irrealis (e.g. hypothetical state of affairs)?
Are verbs marked in a specific mood in counterfactual conditional clauses?
Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of deontic necessity?
Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of epistemic possibility?
Comment: There is potential.

Name: Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of deontic possibility?
Is there morphological marking on the verb used to express indirect commands/wishes etc. directed to the 3Sg?
Is there morphological marking on the verb used to express indirect commands/wishes etc. directed to the 1Sg?
Comment: The IMP.1SG form is included in the Inari Saami dictionary (Sammallahti & Morottaja 1993) but there are no examples of its usage. It can be speculated to be used like this: Čáállum reeivâ (write-IMP.1SG letter-ACC) 'I should write a letter'.

Name: Is it common to use the imperative/jussive in complement clauses introduced by predicates expressing wish/desire/will?
Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of apprehension?
Is there reflexive conjugation?
Are there syntactically ditransitive verbs?
Can non-singular 2nd and 3rd person have the same person/number marking or morphosyntactic treatment?
Can an impersonal (or passive) form be used instead of a finite plural form with an overt subject expression?
Can third person plural verb forms be used for impersonal reference?
Can second person singular verb forms be used in generic meaning?
Are clauses with only infinitive predicates possible?
Can verbs in purposive subordinate clauses be in bare infinitive form?
Are there sentences without overt verbal arguments (e.g. weather verbs)?
Is copula needed for predicate nominals in the 3rd person form of the present tense?
Is a copula needed for predicate nominals in the past and/or future tense?
Can locative adverbial phrases act as predicates without a copula?
Can the same coordinating conjunction be used for NPs, VPs, and clauses?
Does existential negation have a separate operator?
Can standard negation be asymmetric in the present tense?
Can non-finite dependent clauses use the standard negation construction?
Is there a special negator that combines with non-finite forms?
Are there special negative non-finite forms?
Comment: There is also a caritive derivation for nouns and also for verbs, e.g.  viste > viste-ttem 'house - houseless', jäämmiđ > jämi-mettum 'to die - never dying'. There is also an abessive case, meaning 'without': viste : viste-ttáá 'house' : 'without house'.

Name: Is there an impersonal passive construction?
Are there nonfinite forms specialized on the relativization of particular core participants, e.g. subjects (S/A), direct objects (P), absolutive participants (S/P)?
Comment: luuhâm ja luhhum are the same form of a participle but from a different verb (luuhâđ 'to read' and luhhuđ 'to be read').

Name: Are there nonfinite forms that can relativize at least all core participants (S/A/P) and possibly also some noncore participants, e.g. locative adverbials, instruments, etc.?
Are there nonfinite forms that can relativize at least some noncore participants, e.g. locative adverbials or instruments, but cannot relativize all or some of the core participants, e.g. subjects?
Is there a specialized negative participial form, which cannot be analyzed as a specific participial marker + negation marker?
Is there a future participle?
Are there participles that can encode their subject by possessive suffixes?
Can subject in at least some participial subordinate clauses be encoded in the same way as in independent clauses?
Are there participles that obligatorily agree with the nouns they modify in case and number (in all contexts)?
Are there nonfinite forms that can be used both as participles and action nominalizations?
Comment: Perfect participle can be used as action nominalization.

Name: Are there nonfinite forms that can be used both as participles and agentive nominalizations?
Comment: Present participle can be used to express an agent.

Name: Are there nonfinite forms that can be used both as participles and converbs without any additional morphological material, such as case markers?
Is OV the neutral order in affirmative imperative clauses?
Is it possible to place an object between the negative marker and the main verb in imperative constructions?
Are there preverbs?
Comment: There are some verbs with preverbal morphemes fused into them.

Name: Are there verbal prefixes?
Is there diminutive (hypocoristic) marking on verbs?
Comment: There are diminutive (perhaps not hypocoristic) verbal derivates, e.g. smakkiđ > smakkii-stiđ 'to taste - to taste a little'.

Name: Can modifiers of action nominalization in agent and patient roles both be encoded like possessors?
Can the modifier of action nominalization in patient role (e.g. "drinking of coffee") be encoded like the direct object?
Do core adjectives agree with the subject noun in number in the predicative position?
Is it possible to form synthetic superlative?
Can adpositions have person/number marking?
Are there separate adpositions to express goal, source, and location (without there being syncretism)?
Comment: There is the same case for source and location (locative case).

Name: Is case compounding possible?
Are there case categories only found in pronouns?
Does the numeral modification of a noun have an effect on its case selection?
Comment: If NP is in Nominative or Accusative case, the noun can have three different cases, 1 - Nominative, 2-6 - Genitive (accusative) or 7- ... - Partitive. If NP is in any other case, the noun can be inflected to any case and the number will partially agree with the noun.

Name: Is the singular form of the noun also used with numerals bigger than 1?
Is there a genitive case that has an affix?
Comment: The genitive suffix appears only in demonstrative pronouns. Otherwise the genitive forms differ only by stem changes.

Name: Is there a case used to express indirect object/receiver/goal (different from a local case)?
Is there a terminative case?
Is there a separate case to indicate without what/who an action takes place / does not take place?
Is there a separate case to mark the motion along or by the referent of the noun (prolative)?
Is there a locative case that marks goal?
Is there a locative case that marks location?
Comment: The locative case marks both location and source.

Name: Is there a locative case that marks source?
Comment: The locative case marks both location and source.

Name: Is there case syncretism of goal and location marking?
Is there case syncretism of location and source marking?
Comment: The locative case marks for location and source.

Name: Are there two sets of local cases?
Is there a third set of local cases?
Is there a separate case for marking the means by which something is carried out (instrumental) and/or accompaniement (comitative)?
Comment: Comitative case is used in the instrumental and comitative function.

Name: Is there a separate case for marking accompaniment, which is different from the instrumental?
Is there a separate case for marking the result of change (translative) and/or a state of being (essive)?
Comment: There is the essive case, which has both essive and translative function.

Name: Is there a separate case for marking the state of being (essive), which is different from the translative?
Is there a separate morphological marker for expressing equative meaning?
Is there an inflectional nominal marker for expressing benefactive or destinative semantics independent from the dative?
Is there in addition to the basic declension a declension different from a possessive declension?
Is it possible to use singular with paired body parts/clothing/accessories that accompany them?
Can the marking of the possessor in the attributive construction vary?
Can the possessor in the attributive construction be encoded with the nominative?
Is non-singular possession marked in the possessive declension?
Comment: In certain cases there is a difference.

Name: Can 2Sg possessive suffix be used to mark definiteness?
Can 3Sg possessive suffix be used to mark definiteness?
Is there human vs. non-human distinction distinction in independent interrogative pronouns?
When used as a relative pronoun, is it common to use 'who' for animates other than humans?
When used as a relative pronoun, is it common to use 'who' for inanimates?
Can a demonstrative stem be used in the function of a pronoun with 3rd person singular human referent?
Comment: tot 'it' can be used instead of sun 's/he'.

Name: Are there possessive suffixes whose position in relation to case/number suffixes can vary?
Comment: Usually the order is case+px . There is an exception for abessive, where the order is px+case. In comitative and abessive plural, the possessive suffix has divided the case suffix.

Name: Is the order of number and case suffixes fixed across the paradigm the same?
Comment: The number is fused with the case morpheme or with the stem, which makes the question impossible to answer.

Name: Are there different words for mother’s brother and father’s brother?
Are there different words for younger and older relative for other relations than siblings?
Is there animacy distinction for both concepts 'new/young' and 'old'?
Is there distinction for both 'warm' and 'cold' based on whether referring to weather or to temperature of objects?
Is there contrastive length of consonants?
Is there contrastive length of vowels?
Comment: In the first example, the length of the consonant also co-varies, the second example contains a pure minimum pair.

Name: Is there contrast between short and long unstressed vowels?
Comment: Long non-initial vowels are secondary stressed in Inari Saami.

Name: Is there contrast in duration of geminate consonants?
Comment: There are half-long and long geminates (see Türk 2019).

Name: Are there more than two phonological quantities?
Comment: There is a three-way opposition: short, half-long, long (see Markus et al. 2012, Türk 2019).

Name: Are there extralong syllables?
Is the main foot structure trochaic?
Is there lexically distinctive word stress?
Is there morphologically conditioned stress?
Comment: For example, 1st syllable of the derivate -škyettiđ is always stressed independent of what kind of verb it is attached to.

Name: Is there fixed primary stress?
Comment: See also UT122.

Name: Is there stress in heavy syllables?
Is there non-initial primary stress?
Is there palatal vowel harmony?
Is there velar vowel harmony?
Is there labial vowel harmony?
Are there rising diphthongs?
Are there lowering diphthongs?
Comment: Lowering diphtongs are uo, ye, ie, uá, iä.

Name: Is there qualitative contrast between subsets of short and long vowels?
Are there full vs. reduced vowels as contrastive subsets?
Is there front high rounded vowel ü [y]?
Comment: ü [y] may be part of the diphthong ye (as in kye'le), besides that it just appears in some words, e.g. pygálys, pövkkyr.

Name: Is there front midhigh rounded vowel ö [ø]?
Comment: ö [ø] is present only in two loanwords: pövkkyr (< Fin. pöykkyri) and ministeriö (< Fin. ministeriö).

Name: Is there back high unrounded vowel ï [ɯ]?
Is there back midhigh unrounded vowel ë [ɤ]?
Comment: However, it can also be pronounced as [enːnuv].

Name: Is there back low round vowel [ɒ]?
Is there contrast between low and mid front vowels (ä [æ] vs. e [e])?
Are there word-initial consonant clusters?
Are there word-internal consonant clusters in syllable onset?
Are there consonant clusters in syllable coda?
Are there clusters of three or more consonants in a word between vowels?
Are there word-final clusters of three or more consonants?
Are there palatalized dentals?
Are there palatalized labials and velars?
Is there palatal stop [c]?
Is there palatal nasal [ɲ]?
Is there palatal lateral [ʎ]?
Is there phonemic velar nasal [ŋ]?
Is there dental affricate [t͡s]?
Is there non-alveolar affricate (e.g. [t͡ʃ], [͡cɕ])?
Is there a phonological contrast between [s] and postalveolar sibilant [ʃ]?
Are there voiced plosives [b, g, d]?
Comment: When long,  they are voiced, e.g. kobbâ 'white reindeer', säggi 'splinter', koddeđ 'to kill'.

Name: Is there glottal stop [ˀ]?
Is there phonological contrast between plain and labial velar consonants (e.g. [k] vs. [kʷ])?
Is there a constraint on word-initial r?
Is there laryngeal fricative [h]?
Is there voiced velar fricative [ɣ]?
Is there voiceless velar fricative [x]?
Is there voiced dental fricative [ð]?
Is there phonemic labio-velar approximant [w]?
Comment: [v] and [w] are in complementary distribution.

Name: Is there voiceless labiodental fricative [f]?
Is there radical qualitative consonant gradation?
Is there quantitative consonant gradation?
